title: Pence campaigns in Louisiana governor's race as he and Trump hope for runoff
text:
CLOSE President Donald Trump is acknowledging Democrats in the House "have the votes" to begin a formal impeachment inquiry, but he says he's confident it will backfire politically and they won't have the votes to convict in the GOP-controlled Senate. (Oct. 4) AP, AP

KENNER, La. – Vice President Mike Pence and Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., connected Louisiana's upcoming governor's race to the 2020 presidential election as they rallied support for two GOP candidates challenging Democratic Gov. John Bel Edwards.

"Louisiana said yes to Trump in 2016 and we need Louisiana to send a Republican to the governor's office and for Louisiana to vote for four more years of President Donald Trump," Pence told an audience of 250 to 300 supporters Saturday at the Pontchartrain Center.

"It all starts here," said Pence, who never mentioned Edwards by name. "It all starts now."

Rep. Ralph Abraham, R-La., and wealthy Baton Rouge businessman Eddie Rispone are the top two Republicans challenging Edwards, who is the only Democratic governor in the Deep South.

Republicans hope they can keep Edwards from winning outright in the Oct. 12 primary election and send either Abraham or Rispone into a runoff election against the governor, where the dynamics will change.

Trump impeachment inquiry: Vice President Mike Pence gets document request from House Democrats

U.S. Sen. Billy Cassidy (left) and Vice President Mike Pence (right) greet the crowd at a rally held by the LAGOP in Kenner Saturday, Oct. 5, 2019. (Photo: SCOTT CLAUSE/USA TODAY Network)

Neither the state Republican Party nor Pence has endorsed Abraham or Rispone over the other, asking voters to choose one of them in the primary.

"You have two great choices," Pence said.

"(The 2020 presidential election) starts with this race," Cassidy said of the Louisiana governor's race as he introduced Pence. "It's a harbinger."

"You can do your part to set the stage for a great victory next year when we give President Donald Trump four more years," Pence said. "It all works together.

Abraham and Rispone each spoke separately to the crowd before Pence took the stage.

Friction between the two has intensified since Rispone launched a TV attack ad against his fellow Republican.

Impeachment and 2020: Swing-state town hall finds voters more consumed by health care, education than Trump impeachment probe

Abraham has said Rispone is a liar and has asked him to take down the ads that he calls personal attacks.

Rispone accused Abraham of starting the fight.

Neither criticized the other during what the state Republican Party called a unity rally, but both channeled Trump.

"We know the media is against (Trump and Pence)," Abraham said. "They know that as Louisianians we have their backs. It's been an absolute honor to fight side by side with (Trump and Pence) making America great again. As your next governor, I look forward to working with Pence and Trump making Louisiana win."

"We need someone like Trump to bring Louisiana with the rest of the country — a conservative, an outsider, a CEO; that's what we need," said Rispone, who likens his campaign to Trump's. "Louisiana has been run by special interests. I have one special interest: your children and grandchildren."

"The time has come for every Republican to step up and step out and send a Republican governor to state house," Pence said.

Pence's visit comes as the national spotlight grows on the Louisiana governor's race.

Donald Trump Jr. will headline a Republican rally at noon Monday in the University of Louisiana at Lafayette's Cajundome.

The president's son will be joined by Kimberly Guilfoyle, a senior adviser for President Donald Trump’s 2020 campaign, an event hosted and paid for by the Louisiana Republican Party.

Trump and Romney: Trump tears into Mitt Romney who said requests for Ukraine, China to investigate Biden were 'appalling'

Earlier this week the president tweeted asking voters to choose either Abraham or Rispone.

"REPUBLICANS of Louisiana, it is really important for you to go out and vote on October 12th for either Eddie Rispone or Ralph Abraham (both Great), which will lead to a runoff against...." the Republican president tweeted late Tuesday afternoon.

Trump tweet: Anybody but John Bel Edwards in Louisiana governor's race

He continued: "a Nancy Pelosi/Chuck Schumer Democrat (John Bel Edwards), who does nothing but stymie all of the things we are doing to Make America Great Again. Don’t be fooled, John Bel Edwards will NEVER be for us. Early voting has already started!"

Edwards' campaign said the governor has a history of working with Republicans including Trump.

"Gov. Edwards has a long record of working across the aisle at the state and federal level, guiding us through natural disasters and budget crises and giving teachers their first pay raise in 10 years," Edwards campaign spokesman Eric Holl said. "He'll keep putting Louisiana first in his second term."

Greg Hilburn covers state politics for the USA TODAY Network of Louisiana. Follow him on Twitter @GregHilburn1

description: Vice President Mike Pence rallied voters in Louisiana to choose either Ralph Abraham or Eddie Rispone to oust Democratic Gov. John Bel Edwards.
